description.text:
Keep the air off of your part and on your PTFE/PEEK where it belongs!
Well, sometimes I suppose you want to keep the part cool too, but that can lead to brittle pieces. This fan duct keeps nearly all of the air on the extruder parts, while leaking just enough out the bottom to cool the part a little, without leading to brittle pieces.
Install between your Greg's X-carriage and cooling fan, as shown in the image.

title: Dragon Extruder Cover for Zortrax M200

description.text: My love affair with Robwzor's GlowaSmoka continues. I wanted my Zortrax M200 to have a dragon figurehead, but didn't want it to block the temperature-indicating light from my Z-Temp, so I printed the extruder cover in Taulman Blu-Print, which has good transparency, easy support removal, and a nice silvery sheen. I printed it without infill in order to maximize light transmission and minimize weight. Cycling through the colors on power-up: https://youtu.be/o--cryzHawg Printing at around 215ºC: https://youtu.be/Uzsbo2IqCjI

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Yes

290 microns

Infill:

Light

Notes: The attached zcode file was generated with Z-ABS profile (temperature reduced to 265ºC with Z-Temp) "high" speed, 30º ("light") support, 4 layers top/bottom, 60% fan, normal seam and "Mesh" infill, i.e. hollow, i.e. no infill in order to keep weight low and transparency high.

comments.text: You're welcome!  It will work better if you can print PCTPE.  PLA just isn't flexible enough to get past the bends.  Maybe ABS?, but Taulman's Nylon is much easier to print with if you can get your hotend up to 240 - 245°.  It's a little expensive, but a handy plastic to have around.

Printing this by itself would be weird. I'm expecting people to use openscad or some cad program to attach the STL model to another STL model , and essentially attach this as a feature to another project. In other words, I don't think people should have to make servo mounts of this category any more. But you'll have to also scale it up to 102%! I started with Christian_Emsbach's awesome servo mount, imported it into OpenScad and I added the hole for the power/pwm cable. The hole is big enough for the connector to fit through. I also made the bottom become thicker so that it has a stronger foundation upon whatever it is attached. I don't know how to describe the size and shape of servo this is, but it's pretty standard. The servo I have in front of me is a HiTEC HS-311 'standard' servo, and it fits this servo mount. OH yah, if you want to play with the scad script, you must have it in the same directory as Christian_Emsbach's file: servo_mount_v.1.stl so that the import command works
  • JANUARY 26 2016 UPDATE:
    I replaced the files with newer versions. The print should not need support any more (unless you really want it to be perfect). The servos I have come with a little sleeve protecting the cable that comes out of the servo so I had to add a slot to allow me to slide the servo in. This design is tested and does work with the HiTEC HS-311, but the fit is extremely snug if I use the original scale. I tried 102% and it fit perfectly.
    • So, if you want to be able to comfortably fit your servo into this design, you probably should use 102% scale.
  • FEBRUARY 29 2016 UPDATE: I have recently used this design in my Open Emag Electromagnet Wrapping Machine: (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1371831) project. In that project, the servo only sits snug inside this design (at 102% scale), and there is no glue or screws or anything actually holding it in. This is fine for my particular project, but you may want some other design if there's a worry about the servo sliding up and out. For example, this would not be good for steering an off-road RC car. The holes on the design don't seem to line up for mounting. Luckily, mounting the servo with screws is unnecessary for the Open Emag project.

comments.text:
Nice!
I merged it to some part with blender and the Servo is fixed to its point.
comments.author: Nibbels

description.text: This is a pair of male and female sockets for IKEA LEDBERG LED strips. This lets you connect multiple strips together over distance or at odd angles using wire. These are designed to be filled with 22 gauge solid core wire (or similar). Multi-filament wire also works if you twist it; it'll work even better if you tin it. These connectors can actually mate with each other, so they could be used for applications other than the LEDBERG lights. If doing such, you'll almost certainly want to use solid core wire. All units are in mm. I track the .scad source in my The Mµseum project on github.

I printed this on a Lulzbot AO-101 using Slic3r to generate gcode. The source file has the parts rotated so that they'll print well on an extrusion printer as-is.  
Assembly is simple: just cut some wire, making sure to leaving plenty of extra to fit through the connectors. If using solid-core wire, there are some extra holes to make wire hooks on the male connectors. I attempted the same on the female connectors, but it was hard to get inside the connector to bend it.

OK if your one with your 3D printer you may find the next step will be easier for you than it was for me. Since the cold weathers has come in, me and my printer haven't been seen eye to eye !!!! 1.With your knife clean all edges make sure there is no blobs on the corners
2.Apply superglue along one of the long edges ( NOT THE BOTTOM EDGE )
3.grab one more segment and place in the Jig holding the glued side to the new segment (HOLD UNTIL DRY)
4.Keep adding segments to the Jig until the shape is made
5.Rinse and repeat until you have 11 sections like you seen in the pic STEP 3 (PIC 3) Setting up & more GLUING !!! 1.SO place 5 of your newly made segments together and apply glue wait for 10 minutes then apply more !!!
2.Repeat again so you have 2 large halves
3.interlock the 2 large halves together and apply more glue leave to dry for 15 minutes STEP 4 (PIC 4) Last segment & sealing up 1.Add you last segment to the top of the star then glue in place (wait for 5 minutes)
2.your star might have gaps where the segments have joined so apply a thin amount of clear silicone. i would advise you ask for help to hold the star as its very light in weight. depending on you brand of silicone leave to dry for a minimum of 10 hrs STEP 5 (PIC 5) PRINTING FIXTURES. Adding fixture !! LAST STEP !!
1.Loose fit block onto light fixture as seen in pic
2.Apply glue to blocks, sick them to the top as shown in the pic
once dry the light fixture should pivot back and forth this will allow easy access to the bulb.
3.Fit around rose of the light bulb and your done hope you guys enjoyed this this was real fun to make. My son loves the light he now calls it "the magic light" FOR MORE DESCRIPTION PLEASE FOLLOW LINK AND VOTE !!! http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Glow-Star/ Please give some feedback on how you thought i presented. It's been real fun working on this project and hope to see your twist on this design Thanks for looking SCRUMPY JACK

This is a demonstration piece to show printing onto fabric. Inspired by http://cubify.com/store/fabricate . Once printed the piece can be sewn onto a garment.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Additional material Mesh fabric Overview The basic idea is to sandwich the fabric in between layers of the print. The holes in the mesh mean the the plastic sticks to the plastic below and the model will stick firmly to the fabric. If you try printing directly onto the fabric the plastic not stick very well. Instructions
  • Start the print.
  • Pause the print after the first layer or two. Most printers will allow you to do this. On a Makerbot use the "Change filament" option from the menu, this pauses the print and moves the print head out of the way.
  • Lay the mesh smoothly over the print. Use tape or clips to hold the edges down.
  • Resume the print.
    • Let it finish and you are ready to start sewing.

This is a plexiglass case that can be laser cut for the iPad Pro. It was cut from 1/4" acrylic sheet and there are three layers that make up the case. The back sheet has four holes that are threaded 1/4-20 to accept stainless steel cap head bolts. The front sheets utilize through holes. The top and bottom sheet could be cut from thinner sheet but you would need to readjust holes to accept a finer thread to allow for more threads.

title: Trinity symbol
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is one of the symbols used to represent the Christian belief in a Triune God - one God in three persons - Father, Son and Holy Spirit.  The circles represent that each person of the trinity is eternal.  Interlocking circles show that they have common attributes yet still remain as individual personages.  The triangle emphasizes the unity of the one true God in three persons.

title: ReprapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller 12864 Wall Mount Folding Case with Lights and Switches
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
ReprapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller 12864 Folding case with lights and switches. Yet another case for the ReprapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller 12864.
This was designed to have perfect printing condition and a nice look because the down pannel folds to get the right angle and keep a good aspect.
It's a one single part case, printable with no support, no brim, no skirt. You can print the RepRap plug to hide the mounting screws. Features & BOM :
  • many features in a small case.
  • wall mountable with two 4mm screws (8x1gauge)
  • the foldable pannel mounts with two Din 912 M3*10 screws
  • 1 slot for a full sise P+N 4 pins inexpensive rocker switch (search "KCD4" on Aliexpress)
  • 2 slots for two inexpensive 6mm metal rocker switches for lights or fans (search "MTS202" on Aliexpress)
  • 2 slots for 5mm leds for control purpose
  • I slot to access to the SD card reader by the side.
  • You need four Din 912 M3*10 to mount the Controller.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Best print : 0.3mm Nozzle, 0.2 layers, 3 walls, 5 layers for top and bottom

Infill:

100%

Notes: Don't be affraid to print with 100% infill. It will brings the needed strenght to the case, and the infill areas are reduced, so it's not a long pringting time part. There's a "weak" line to allow the bottom pannel to fold to the case. It works with both PLA and ABS.
Folding instructions. Just fold the bottom pannel to the case then secure it with two Din912 M3*10mm screws. It's an easy operation which can be achieved by a single person.

Why yet another 12864 display case ? Well, as usual, you never find exactly all the features you need in "things".
Before to design this one, I printed 3 cases from thingiverse and found unpleasant issues : fragile case, unaligned holes, too big footprint for a not so big display, unpratical mounting holes, no possible extensions or switches inside, two or 3 parts case... As I installed my printer in a heat chambre, I needed a compact control panel which allows me to turn the printer on, eventualy turn on lights or cooling fans, control the printer, and all that outside the box in a single front pannel. That two angled pannels allows to hold all the features in a small footprint. That case size is comparable to other 12864 cases I printed by the past. Last, I wanted a single print part with no more post production thant to fold and fix the bottom pannel to close the shape. To me it's contains all I ever needed. It's one of the parts I printed two years ago and never wanted to upgrade and/or replace.
The foldable pannel allows to have the two front pannels nice and clean. I dismantled 2 or 3 times the pannel to unplug things for maintenance (fans getting noisy, and so...) and the pannel is still stong like new. The design is very simple, and the parts prints easily. No need to dig holes or so. The Reprap plug hides the mounting screws and makes the enclosure nice and clean. The shape is simple with elegant round corners and display that cames flush to the case. Because I used everyday during two years with nothing to blame on it, so I decided to share that "yet another .

UPDATE: I no longer publish on Thingiverse. For those wishing the Sketchup Design Files for Saber, they are here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/saber and here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/26924. Both locations "saber.zip". Best wishes. ** UPDATE!!!** The prototype Saber has been running a little over a year. By our calculations, taking 1 stride every 2 seconds equates to 30 strides a minute, 1800 strides per hour, 43,200 strides per day, and 15,768,000 strides per year. With a rear leg stride of 5 inches, that equates to approximately 1500 miles non stop (Saber runs on a bench with a UPS, and the shop has a 65kw backup generator, so Saber hasn't stopped for over a year).

Thanks Thingiverse for the feature of Saber! As always, I am truly humbled and honored. And many thanks to those who liked and collected Saber! NOTES: 1) See UPDATES below for updates to the design and files. 2) The original Saber is motorized. If you wish to hand operate your Saber, I've uploaded a hand crank module that replaces the motorized module here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1368351. END OF NOTES. Saber is my interpretation of, and was inspired by, the "Disney Computation Designs of Mechanical Characters" video, "Cyber Tiger" segment (link to video follows below). If you are in the Dallas, Texas, USA area on January 31 through February 2 2016, and want to see Saber in person, attend the SolidWorks convention and visit the Ultimaker booth as Saber and some of my other Ultimaker 2 printed designs will be there, as will I. I would enjoy meeting all of you who attend. As to the development of Saber, Thingiverse member sofiadragon1979 suggested that I design and print this thing after seeing "Perseverance" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:348489) which was inspired by the same Disney video, and of course Sisyphus (thanks sofiadragon1979 for the suggestion!) . Not having access to the original details, plans nor software that Disney used, I took liberties in the design of the framework, gear train and arms by using my own software (now I know why trigonometry class was useful, who knew?) and design tools in order to better accommodate 3D printing. Standing almost 204mm (8") tall, and when fully extended 304mm (12") long (from head to toe), Saber is quite large, yet it was designed such that it is printed in smaller components in an effort to allow a wider variety of 3D printers to print it. Saber is the most mechanically detailed Thingiverse thing I've published and is indeed a challenge to print and build, so please do not hesitate to comment if you have questions, problems, complaints, suggestions or whatever, and I'll do my best to address them. I hope you build one, and I hope you enjoy it! Video of Saber prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KSYqz6YY63c. Some have expressed interest in the software I wrote to assist in the design of Saber. A short video of it simulating the front left leg design is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TbzAQyXUwXs. Video of Sabers made for friends and clients here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5f6ZmdwUVzE. More Sabers here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yCFsUsHfFYQ. And last yet certainly not least, the inspirational Disney video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfznnKUwywQ. Designed using my own software (to generate the framework, gear trains, cam, cap, axle and arm motions) and Sketchup Make 2015. The prototype was printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill). All subsequent Sabers were printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2 Extended using Cura default settings. UPDATES: Sorry for the update delay as my wife's father, a retired Detroit, MI. police officer, passed away during the December 2015 holidays. My wife and I dedicate Saber to his memory. 1) Uploaded new "Head Right.stl". Old one is not correct, sorry for any problems. 2) Uploaded new "Head Right.stl". Previous upload didn't work, sorry for any problems. 3) Uploaded close up gear train photo of Saber prototype showing the correct initial positioning for "Arm Axle.stl" components for the left side. The right side "Arm Axle.stl" components are rotated 180 degrees from those on the left side. The positions indicated in "Assembly.skp" and "Assembly.stl" are not correct and I will update both as soon as possible, sorry for the problem. 4) For those with large format printers, I've uploaded "Base One Piece.stl", a one piece base.

Parts I Purchased: 1) Motor: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009N81HES?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00. 2) Coaxial Power Jack: Radio Shack part number 274-1583. 3) 3.0 Vdc Power Supply: Radio Shack part number 273-315 with the "N" style plug 273-345, you get one free with the power supply. Tools and supplies I used: 1) Rubber mallet. 2) Small vise. 3) Flat punch set. 4) Modeling knife. 5) Small files. 6) Sandpaper. 7) Slip joint pliers. 8) Needle nose pliers. 9) Thick cyanoacrylate glue. 10) Cyanoacrylate accelerator. Instructions: Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. If the tight fitting components are too loose, add a small dot of cyanoacrylate to each side of the pin, allow to dry completely (I use accelerator to speed the process), then try the fit again. Repeat until tight. Assemble as per Assembly.skp (or Assembly.stl). I started by pressing the two frame halves together ("Frame Left.stl" and "Frame Right.stl") and then one by one, inserted a gear ("Gear.stl") with its associated components (either "Arm Axle.stl", "Cap Axle.stl", or "Cap Axle Eccentric.stl") into the assembled frame and tested each gear assembly as I progressed to make absolutely sure each gear assembly rotated with almost zero effort and zero snags, and if it did not, I removed the most recently installed gear assembly and trimmed, filed, sanded, etc. until it did. Once completed, while holding onto "Cap Motor.stl", you should be easily able to spin the entire assembly by hand. If not, disassemble and repeat the process, as this is a very important step. Another very important step, pay very exact attention to the initial orientation of the components "Cap Axle Eccentric.stl" and "Arm Axle.stl" as shown in the left side close up gear train photo. The right side components are installed 180 degrees out of phase with the left side. Lubricate all moving components with petroleum jelly. Wire the motor such that it rotates counter clockwise as viewed from the motor shaft. My Sabers run anywhere from 1.5 to 6 VDC. It was designed for use with the selected motor at 3 VDC which minimizes noise while providing good motion. For break in, after lubrication, I ran my prototypes for 2 hours at 6 VDC, then lowered the voltage to 3.0 VDC. They've been running for months now at 3 VDC. Comment if questions, and best of luck with this one!

description.text:
The Libro-Struder is an original 3d printer extruder created at the Pueblo City-County Library District. It is part of the RepRap Libro project but is a general purpose filament extruder for all your filament-pushing needs. It uses plastic-on-plastic friction forces rather than toothed-gear biting forces to grip and advance a plastic filament. The Libro-Struder is less prone to jamming and slipping than the more common Wade or Bowden-type extruders. It can also be created with fewer specialized parts. The design explores the idea of using taken-apart pop rivets as tiny bushings on shafts. The current model does require a stepper motor that has an orbital gearbox attached. I have had much success with a Nema 17 stepper with a 27:1 gearbox, Part No. 17HS19-1684S-PG27. Hackers encouraged to print their own gearbox. :-)
Original design by David Hartkop, Technology Trainer PCCLD. Hardware:
Nema 17 motor, 27:1 gearbox #17HS19-1684S-PG27
4 x M3x8mm screws
Push-in pneumatic fitting for 4mm od nylon tube
18 gage steel wire, 3 inches
22 x 1/8” x 1/4” long pop rivets, steel.
nut #10 (M5)
set screw #10 x 3/16" long (M5x5mm long). Printed Parts:
motorGalaxy
topGalaxy
bigGear
IOModule
smallGears (11)
motorMount Notes: -> Movement of the central gear is slow and continuous while movement of the smaller gears undulates as they periodically engage and the spring arms flex slightly. -> The center hub of the big gear is held tightly to the motor shaft with a set screw in an inserted nut. The hub is reinforced by wrapping some bare stranded copper wire around its groove 6-8 times and then soldering around it. This creates a metal band that is fused into the plastic. -> Print Settings for Parts: All were printed in ABS 1.75mm filament
Big Gear: 4 shells, 75% infill, 0.3mm/layer, no supports
Small Gear: Same as big but just 2 shells.
I/O Module: 2 shells, 25% infill, 0.3mm/layer raft & support
Galaxies: 3 shells, 25% infill, 0.3mm/layer, raft, support for motorGalaxy -> The Big Gear's nut and set screw are #10 and #10 x 3/16" long (M5, M5x5mm long). YouTube Videos: See video the Libro-Struder power loading here: https://youtu.be/CCGOJw2fUM8
See video of the Libro-Struder extruding here: https://youtu.be/b2AEpmFmc_0
See video of dragging filament out of the Libro-Struder: https://youtu.be/2r9iNOMyIR0

author: el_diabolo

title: Charging stand for iPhones 4S and earlier

description.text:
For as many iPhone stands as I've seen on Thingiverse, I never saw one that was just like this -- holds the iPhone in a portrait orientation while allowing you to charge it, and fits the iPhone 4 models and earlier (the wider charger port).  Maybe there is one and I just couldn't find it in the sea of similar designs.  So I designed my own.  
This lets me set my iPhone in a position that works well for it to work as an alarm clock while it's still plugged in so it's charging overnight.  That's all.  Doesn't try to hold the charge cable in place or anything, it just lets you feed it up into place and that's that.  (Best thing is to pull it up through, connect to the phone, then drop it back through as you set the phone down.)

Probably a good candidate for printing with a brim since there's a fairly large number of layers and a fairly small bed-touching surface area.  Otherwise, nothing special is required.  
Fishing that cable through is a bit tricky at first but have patience, it can be done.  You will probably need to carefully trim and clean and file first though, if your printer leaves any hair or schmutz.

author: faizaniqbal

description.text:
Inspired by Doilys and double sided train station benches, Double Doily is fabricated from 1/4 powder-coated aluminum.
After 9/11, I began working in a round format. My doily inspired pieces have evolved into large-scale public sculptures. My work moved from inside my studio outdoors into trees, onto concrete Jersey Barriers and into public spaces like ferry terminals, Brooklyn Streets and sculpture parks. Instead of working alone, I now collaborate with many others, public authorities, government agencies, art consultants, sculpture Parks, engineers, curators, arts administrators, fisherman, installers, fabricators, tailors and architects.
My Pieces can be made from a variety of materials, aluminum, plastic, vinyl, fabric, mosaic, glass and steel. They hang, divide, adorn, and shelter referencing architecture and nature. My goal is to integrate the flavor of domestic handiwork into the built environment.
Having worked with found laces and doilies for years in my studio, I needed a way to make large-scale outdoor work, translating something intimate and private into something large and public. I use computers and laser cutting technology to produce my needlework inspired artwork.
This is a simple design created from 2 folded doilies.

description.text:
http://youtu.be/gGpVgxmxidM Inspired by most skater belt buckles, our 3D Printed buckle is a simple design that works with most grosgrain belts. The four piece design uses a latch that grips onto the belt by clipping it down. The cover is really interesting because it can be customized to have your name or logo. Combing this with a bright color that really pops can create an awesome style worthy of an Instagram. Designed in Autodesk Maya, I used basic modeling techniques to create the pieces and carefully measured them so it fits the belt nice and tight. After a few prototypes we got the tolerance issues down and each piece holds together quite nicely. Also avilable on Etsy
http://www.etsy.com/listing/153729526/mustache-belt

The pieces easily snap together and only requires one piece to be glued for assembly. The buckle is pretty durable and lightweight. The teeth in the latch and cover are sharp and tightly hold your belts adjustments for a nice fit.  
It's an ABS print that has a layer height resolution of 200 microns and takes about 30 minutes to print all the prints separately. The assembly is easy and only takes about two minutes. Cause you know, gotta let the glue dry...

title: Heavy Duty Rack Handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a heavy duty handle for racks. This handle is fixed with strongs 4mm screws (8x2) and offers a strong grip. The handle is comfortable to the hand especialy while pulling. I use them for two years to move a weighty drawer and they never failed.
That handles are made to be strong, not to be cute, they do what they're meant to do. Good stuff.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Best print : 0.3mm Nozzle, 0.2 layers, 4 walls, 6 layers for top and bottom

Infill:

50 to 100%

Notes: You can choose a infill from 50 to 100% depending of the strenght needed. 50% can hold at last a 30kg load (60lbs), that's how I use it daily since two years. You can increase the infill if you want to hold heavy machinery or so. Raise the printer temperature as high as possible for your filament, to get a strong bond between layers.
Post Printing Just remove the support and use countersink head screws.

You said heavy duty, uh ? Well, that's realy what I wanted ! I download handles, but any of them could just hold light stuff. I had to move a heavy drawer with my 3d Printer on it and the overall weight exceeds 30kgs (60lbs). I did not wanted button style handles. As musician, most of my equipment is rackable and heavy components wear strong handles. I wanted to design handles as strong as these professionnal equipment ones. The shape is inspired by audio racks handles. I just refined a bit the shape to make that handle realy comfortable. The design is discreet and functional. Nothing fancy. When I designed that handle, I was trying different ways to include my monogram in a printable way. I tryed different things on any print I made during this period. So that part holds my monogram. It can be grinded out easily if you don't like it.

Here are small models, actually relief maps, of Mound Fuji and Mount Etna. The models were constructed using NASA's SRTM3 data set. http://dds.cr.usgs.gov/srtm/version2_1/ Height data for most of the earth is available at 3 arc-second intervals. The data comes as "tiles" one degree latitute and longitude on a side. Each tile contains 1201 rows and 1201 columns of two byte signed integers. Fortran code very similar to that described in thing:118327 was used to write the openSCAD polyhedron commands that constructed the models. Stl files are Fuji.stl and Etna.stl. The fortran code that makes the polyhedron commands is included.

Both models can be constructed directly on the build platform.  On my Replicator they print in about an hour.  
The lengths of the model sides are 25 arc-minutes.  Mount Fuji is 3776 meters and Mount Etna 3350 meters high.  
The models are oversampled and can be scaled up to show more detail.

description.text:
This latch won't budge until you pull up on the lever - just what you need for an RV or boat where shifting contents can cause a normal latch to spring open.  And it has an integral printed spring that makes it snap shut with a satisfying click.  It is designed for flush 12mm door panels and  latches directly onto a 1" thick face frame.  (I've included the design files so you can customize for other panel and face frame thicknesses.)  It works with both doors and drawers.
I've also included the file for printing your own hinges!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

The latch uses a 1 1/8" long #6 screw for the pivot.  You'll need to cut a notch in your panel 1.025" wide by 0.850" deep to hold the latch.  You can secure the latch in place with two 18 gauge brads.
The hinge halves are identical - print two per hinge.  Use a 1 1/2" long 4D finish nail for the hinge pin.  If the nail hole is too tight, you may want to drill it the hole out with a 5/64ths drill.  Mount the hinges with #6 screws.

author: TK_DESIGN

description.text: I have a great little trailer that I use to haul everything. The problem is that the eyelets on the tarps don't line up with the tie-downs on the trailer to allow the tarp to pull tight and/or straight. Here is the solution I came up with: The small hole is the bungee hook hole. The 'disco ball' gets wrapped in the tarp, then pushed through the large hole and pulled through far. The tarp is then slid along the keyhole section and pulled tight, the disco ball then disallows the tarp from pulling through and allows you to attach the bungee at any point on the tarp. If you put the disco ball on the inside of the tarp. it allows the bungee to also hold the tarp ends down a little thereby reducing some of the flapping in the wind. This is not designed to be used on the same spot on the trap over and over. If you have the tarp on the trailer or load for a long time, make sure you check the wear on the tarp and/or move locations on the tarp to make sure you don't rip through. (The hole in the disco ball is to allow you to tie it to a location on the trailer so you know where it is at any time.) I'll have pics of how I have mine set up soon.

Added a few pics of the printed clips. (I like the word clips) I hope they are enough to let you know how this works. I just realized that the bungee hook hole is too small for the new plastic bungee hooks. I'll get a new version up this evening. 4 clips with enlarged bungee holes and lanyard holes. These are the updated versions I said I'd make weeks ago. The holes for the bungees are much larger to work with the newer plastic bungees, and there are holes to allow you to tether the disco balls to the actual clip so they stay with each other in storage. I'd recommend a lanyard about 2' long to allow them to be clipped a foot in from the tarp's edge if you need. Updated again This version has the larger bungee hole but also has tapered sides to allow the lanyard to wrap around for when it is in storage. Will post pics when I print them.

Need a wall mount for Your DeWalt cordless drill? - or probably many other devices....

comments.text:
I printed a couple of these using PLA Pro (PLA+) which is stronger than the ABS I have been using. .2mm layer height.. Works beautifully, love the convenience. Also printed one for a friend. However, after about 2 weeks of use, mine failed. Basically, split about 1.5" away from the wall. My friend's did the same about a week after mine. The top layer/shelf It is also slightly bowed from the weight of the drill constantly hanging on it. So, I glued mine back together and added some diagonal bracing from the bottom of the wall bracket to the inside edge of the collet receptor. I would recommend a couple things on a redesign. First, unless you want to store the drill with a bit in it, I would shorten the horizontal length to the point where you can barely fit a second battery pack on top, and/or change the angle of the chuck receptacle to be a bit more vertical relieving some of the stress on the wall plate/shelf intersection. Second, I recommend you extend the bottom angular brace under the top plate to basically be bigger, reach further out and also extend further down on the wall bracket. This would also help relieve the stress on the shelf and brace. But, I love the concept, and hopefully a new design can address the issues we encountered.
Thanks
Don

title: A Rocket Ship in the Classic Style

description.text:
I designed this rocket ship model as yet another overhang test. It was inspired by the ship created by Wallace and Grommit in "Wallace and Grommit: A Grand Day Out." View ship here:
http://cf1.imgobject.com/backdrops/dfe/4bc90873017a3c57fe002dfe/wallace-gromit-a-grand-day-out-original.jpg I streamlined the basic shape and tapered the doorway in order to reduce the angle of overhangs because I was trying to be nice to my printer.

Print with 3D Printer.  The wall thickness (and fins) are fairly thin, so use a solid infill print setting.  No supports are necessary (at least in my experience with ABS).
Sometimes the rafts print well and contribute to the effect of the "engines" on the fin tips.

remixed_from.title: The banana XY bushing block and belt tensioner. Drop in replacement for the ultimaker

title: Mooncactus XY for plastite screws (no nuts!) + a bushing-retaining lip

description.text:
This is a very minor modification to Mooncactus's XY blocks.  We changed some hole sizes so that it is assembled with 2 #2 0.5" (McMaster PN 99512A162) and 4 #2 0.75" (Mcmaster PN 96001A164) plastite screws instead of M3 machine screws and nuts. We also added a little lip that holds the bushing captive, so you don't have to clamp as tightly in order to hold it in place. Too much clamping force can deform the bushing, which causes motion problems.  
Reuse  Mooncactus's banana part to suit your belt length...  
Use McMaster Part 94669A612 as a standoff to protect the belt from the sharp screw threads where it is being clamped.

comments.text:
I've made these. Assembled them to check the parts. Not yet installed. I noticed the the holes in the two 'to be tapped' holes in the Bottom_tab part offered noticeably greater resistance to the STS than did the corresponding holes in the Bottom_no_tab parts.
The Bottom_tab holes felt 'correct' the others felt too large. Are they definitely the same design size?
If so, it must be something that I've done differently between the two types, but I can't imagine what.
comments.author: mgg942

comments.text: It is possible that the sizing is different. There are so many similar files with this design I might have uploaded the wrong one. Print orientation + settings also make a huge difference on the ID's of small holes.

Smaller effector plate for the Dreammaker OverLord Pro & non pro. Centers the nozzle and should get a print diameter of 180 ~190 mm on the OL Pro. It uses the stock 60mm rod spacing on the sides so you don't need to replace the OEM carriages. Use a M2.5mm tap on the holes, a 3/32 (2.5mm)drill should be enough if you just want to force the screws in. You can reuse all of the original hardware. I calculate the delta radius should be about 110. You'll need to redo the calibration on your printer. Also make sure that each of the sides is EXACTLY 60mm, Trim or shim as necessary so you don't have any geometry errors. I used the cooling duct from this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1084213 ToDo: Possibly redesign a layer cooling duct for a blower fan so I can make it even smaller.

comments.text: Do you still use this plate? I wonder how much does the original plate weighs. I figure a printed plate like this could give more print speed and reduce backlash as well to the printer.
comments.author: AFIF

comments.text: To be honest this printer has been in the closet as I built a new bot. There is so much weight in other parts of the effector that this won't really make much difference. Also there is so much slop in other parts of the system, carriage bushings, rod ends,belt idler bearings, that excess weight is the least of your worries.
comments.author: AFIF

comments.text:
Do you reuse all the hardware from the original effector, Traxxas' & all?
I also believe that the distance between the diagonal rods for each carriage remains the same (as you didn't specify), because otherwise the carriages should also be re-designed.
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: Yes it has the same 60mm offset as the original and all of the original hardware was used. I have mounted everything but times been short so I have not had time to re-calibrate and test. I'll update with some pictures.

author: Cyb3rCat

description.text:
This is a water dish I designed for my cats. Even filling their water dish twice a day, it was too small and would occasionally be empty. I decided that if I was going to print a new dish, I would make it the kind that is fed with a water bottle. I looked on Thingiverse, and while there was one design, I didn't care for some aspects of it, so instead of reworking that one, I just made my own.
The design looks like a fish, very similar to a certain kind of snack cracker. The tail serves as a support for the water bottle to help keep it from tipping, and the bowl has a rim around it to prevent it being knocked over. (Determined cats will always find a way, but I haven't had any issues so far.) The bowl itself holds a good amount of water even without the bottle attachment, I may make another file that matches as a food/water dish without the bottle.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I printed with 0.2 Layer Height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

description.header: Be sure you are using food-safe PLA!
description.text:
As this dish will be in constant contact with water your pets will drink, you want to be sure you're not using any potentially hazardous plastic material. Double check your filament to ensure it is food safe. You will need a build width or length of about 23cm to fit this print. If I get requests, I may do another version to fit a smaller print bed, but because it needs to be water tight, it will never fit a smaller print bed like a 100mm. Layer height could be 0.1 or 0.2, the bottle screw most likely won't work at higher resolutions. No supports or rafts are needed. I don't recommend supports, but you can use a raft if you need to.
  • Bottom Solid Layers: up to you, 2 or 3 is sufficient
  • Shell/Side Layers: 3 or 4, depending on your printer and settings. I personally used 3.
  • Top Solid Layers: 4. You may get away with 3, but 4 definitely will work.

If part of the fin curls If the tips of the tail curls and separates from the build platform, it won't hurt the dish. You can use a heat gun, or hair dryer (assuming you used PLA) to warm the tip tail and bend it flat again. A pretty easy process and doesn't need to be perfect. Cleaning Cleaning is going to be more difficult than for a smooth injection-moulded plastic part due to the surface texture. When cleaning the bowl, use a hard bristled scrub brush like the kind used for scrubbing pots. As long as you are only using water, and regularly change it, it should rarely need cleaning. If algae or something seems to be growing into/inside the plastic, I recommend getting rid of the bowl. I've used mine in a tropical climate where algae is a constant problem and have yet to have issues. If the bottle leaks For me, I didn't have any issues with the bottle leaking, however depending on your printer and the print quality, it's possible it may happen. If so, use an O-ring at the bottom of the area where the bottle screws in. Generally though, this really shouldn't be necessary because the design means that any water from around the bottle threads would end up in the bowl anyway.
I used Sketchup to design the bowl, which is very easy to use and free for non-commercial use. :)

comments.text: Please don't use that too much, 3D printed objects are essentially petri dishes, lots of bacteria will grow.
comments.author: hofcake

comments.text: The main concern is that food particles will be trapped in the plastic texture. As this is a water bowl, this isn't much of a issue. The dormant bacteria already present in the water won't have anything to eat, and will remain dormant. However, if you are concerned you can easily coat the bowl with polyethylene food safe coating, available at hardware stores. It will seal the plastic and make a smoother surface. You could also use fewer shell layers if you plan to coat it.
comments.author: hofcake

description.text:
Bracket to hold the dog door cover above the dog door when not in use. 
This attached to the vertical surface and the dog door cover slides right in between the brackets.  I have a bracket on the right and left and one at the bottom.  
Due to the curves in the door I had to use a different bracket on the bottom.  At first I made a complex shape that curved along the contour (see 45 degree bracket) but I couldn't screw the bracket in because the wood is too thin at the point that it connects.  Instead I made a simple flat bracket for the bottom.
Feel free to download and modify.  Let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement.

This is a y axis tensioner for a FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3. You will need M3x12 screws for mounting the motor, M4x16 for the jack screws, and M4x8 screws and t-nuts(reuse these from the Folger mount)
Tap the tensioner holes with a M4 tap. You can turn the wiring connector to the back. Finger tight on the belt should be enough.
This will allow you to tension the belt as tight as you want. Mine was a drop in replacement, without even changing the belt length. 
Printed in ABS, .3 layer height, 25% infill, with no support. The adjustment slots may need some droopy bits trimmed out after printing.

author: getitfixed

description.text:
A stubby radio antenna to suit a Honda S2000.
The point of this antenna is to replace my Honda S2000 OEM antenna with one that is shorter and won't bend when a heavy car cover is fitted over the vehicle. It could replace a lost OEM antenna too I guess. Basically the stub is printed in ABS, the hole is tapped to a M5 thread about 15mm deep, find a 20mm length of M5 threaded rod (cut up a surplus M5x25 screws thread), solder a 3-4mm dia pen spring to the top end of that rod, then screw into printed stub housing and set with CA glue if it's not tight enough.

author: michiganfpv

title: Stethoscope directional cone for engine noise finding

description.text:
Vey simple 30mm cone for plugging into a cheapy stethoscope set bought online (like $5).
The stethoscope comes with a doctors type diaphragm pickup, but to find noisy bearings on my cars accessories (A/C, alternator, P/Steering etc) I found that it's less than good. So I replaced it with a simple cone which works better for this purpose.
Even individual injectors can be heard ticking away individually with it...
I didn't put any science into the design, but it works OK.

author: michiganfpv

description.text: just another 3D doodle

I got sucked back into airsoft so expect more misc accessories over the months. This one is useful for things like canted sights, maybe a gopro mount, etc. It's meant to use a M4x35mm socket head cap screw and a nylon locknut, but a regular nut could be used too, and if you need an imperial size 8-32 should work as well. If it's tight on your rail either file it or scale up by a few percent. I also tried to make it as low profile as possible.
Added a split version 2015-12-30. The photographs show this version on my airsoft SR25. Note the tight clearance to the scope and how I wanted to use the stock flip-up sights as backup/close range sights.

Update 16 Apr 2017
Added lace locks. Update 15 Mar 2017:

• The profile of the interlocking surfaces has been improved to prevent the cleats from being pulled apart with tightly bound laces.
  • Holes for the laces have been enlarged significantly. Thicker laces are thus supported. For regular/ thinner laces, use the cover strips (see next point) to reduce the hole diameter.
  • Redesigned cover strips (previously known as color strips) now fit into position without the need for glue. The cover strips reduce the hole size to fit regular/ thinner laces. They also allow for a second color on the cleats for extended color matching.
    • (Note: previous version files & images have been removed to avoid confusion. If you need the older version, drop me a message.) ======================================================================= Update 22 Dec 2015: Added files of the color strips. Glue on the strips to make the cleats stronger and also print them in a second color that coordinates with the shoe color to get an even more stylish look. Print a total of 8 strips if gluing two strips onto both sides of every piece cleat. If gluing only one strip on each cleat (ie. total only 4 strips needed), be sure to check that the cleats are properly oriented such that the color strips will all end up facing upwards when the cleats are locked in pairs and attached to the shoe laces. ===================================================================== As if there aren't enough options out there to eliminate tying shoelaces, here's another one from me! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rXmi_FiX0-I I tried the Klots and liked it for a while. But after some use, they can detach when I'm running for some distance. So I designed a different method of locking that will remain secure even during intense activities on my shoes. They are designed to be printed with the long side vertical for maximum holding strength. No supports needed. I printed mine with the Micro 3D printer (M3D) without infill using PLA. If your printer gives poor quality prints like mine, the holes will need to be smoothed out to avoid any rough edges from slicing the shoe laces. If you make one, I would very much like to see your photos of them and read your comments. Thank you!

comments.author: Shifty92

comments.text: I was using the most recent version (as of Oct 2017). It is not that the thing broke apart. It simply opened up when I was running. I was not investigating the issue further. I then removed them and returned to the normal laces without any extra lacing system like cleats or klotz. It may take longer to lace the shoe, but at least it will not open up, when you really need the shoe to stay on your feet.
comments.author: miketanct

comments.text: Are there ways to help keep the pieces together? I find that they they wiggle a little bit and it annoys me. Otherwise great idea, still better than klots.
comments.author: jaymigibbs42

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. I take it that you mean the two pieces don't fit snugly enough when latched? The wriggle room was designed to match my printer (the M3D micro) which has very poor accuracy. The printed pieces on mine become impossible to latch when I further reduce the spacing between the latching surfaces in the design. Only recently did I purchased a better printer (CR-10), so I will soon be able to adjust the design and test print for a better fit that's suited to better accuracy printers. When I do release the next revision, this will surely be incorporated. Meanwhile, what you can do is to slightly thicken the male portion of the latching surface by either applying a layer of epoxy or thick paint enough to reduce the wriggle room and let it dry and harden. If you over-apply and it gets too thick to fit, you can still sand it down accordingly. Hope this suggestion works to your satisfaction. :)
comments.author: jaymigibbs42

comments.text: Yeah, you're right and thanks for the reply. I think I might do the paint thing.
comments.author: miketanct

comments.text: what do you use the lace locks for?

comments.text: For locking the portion of the laces on the final eyelets so that the length of laces being secured don't slip loose under tension.

comments.text: This solves the countless minutes we spend trying to get my sons shoes past his orthotic thanks so much A+++
comments.author: kamular

comments.text: These printed out pretty well; however, I have a love-hate relationship with them.  I've had a few occasions they have broke free but it is variable.  I find I typically do not have enough room to connect them with ease and this puts too much pressure on the connection and causes it to break loose every once in a while.  I've tried various lacing methods and allowing slack but i think the #1 contributor to the issue is that it almost takes me longer to connect them than it does to actually tie my shoes as they are too far apart.  If i had more slack I could move them closer together and it would work well but then my shoe wouldn't be snug.
comments.author: rollingdice007

comments.text: I've just released a newer version that resolves the issue you have encountered. Check it out.
comments.author: rollingdice007

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing your experience!
I gather that yours "broke loose" as in the 2 pieces snapped away from each other without any breakage in the material itself? Or did any of the printed piece broke into smaller pieces?
comments.author: rollingdice007

comments.text: You are correct the connection 'broke loose' as in the 2 pieces snapped away from each other.  If there's enough slack in the laces to prevent them from disconnecting, it appears they link fine (even after you experience them disconnecting once or twice).  It's the lack of slack that kills it.  I'm not entirely sure how the slack issue would be resolved but my .02 cents is that if you widen the pieces so large amounts of slack aren't necessary to connect it - or if you have additional lace holes on the opposite side of the connection pieces (horizontally parallel to the current holes).  I'd also expand the holes just a hair as the aglet on my shoe got busted up after threading them through a few times trying to get the best slack.
comments.author: miketanct

comments.text: I suspect that the main factor of this breaking loose issue could be the gap spacing between the two pieces when put together.  I had to create a larger spacing than most printers would require for a snug fit because of my printer's poor quality prints (bad tolerance). If I had made the spacing smaller, I wouldn't be able to fit the cleats printed on my printer. With my printer, a pair of newly printed cleats have to be pushed hard to fit together the first time so I will pre-wear them a little through many rounds of opening-closing until they become easy enough to assemble. Therefore, creating another version with a tighter tolerance might solve the problem on normal printers, assuming that your prints were already fitting rather loosely fresh out of the printer?
comments.author: rollingdice007

description.text:

title: Raspberry Pi 2 with Hifiberry DAC Case

description.text: Designed a case for my Raspberry Pi 2 with Hifiberry Dac+ Pro (RCA outputs). It is a tight fit and therefor does not need screws or glue, but kinda snaps together. Because the DAC tends to get warm I added vents, which also lets the glow from the LED on the DAC board shine through. Designed in 123D Design, Sliced in Simplify 3D and printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal in PLA.

comments.text:
Hi many thanks for this case was just about to construct one myself when decided to search through thingiverse first.
Your design is just what I was looking for. There is just one small issue since my hifiberry has a lid on top of the RCA plugs to screw them on and I dont want to remove it.
Is there any chance you could share a step file of the top case?

author: rjsals61

description.text:
Purpose of this drilling template is to make sure that two holes have a precise distance from each other, in this case it's 145 mm. But the design is pretty simple and easy to buiuld for other distances.
The way you use it is drill one whole first and then stick the small bolt into the hole. You can then step back and adjust the angle to your needs, probably works best vertically. The human brain is usually very good at telling angles so you probably don't need a spirit level. But if you wanna be 100% sure draw a line on the wall after drilling the first hole.
This can be printed with low resolution, i did it with 0.3 mm layer height.

title: Spool extender clips for SainSmart filament spools

description.text: The SainSmart ABS filament is great, however they come in cardboard spools that are too small for 1 kg of material and the filament tends to slide out.  These clips were designed to virtually extend the spool to eliminate the issue.  They are pressed into the cardboard and can be reused.  I use eight per spool as shown in the photo and they work great.
The original source file is a parametric design and it was created using OpenSCAD.  After all tests a final design resulted and that is the design I am submitting as STL.

Create substances with covalent bonding! Customize the atoms to be whichever atom you want, pick the number of bonds, specify the length of the bond, and you're all set! This is my first openscad project, so tell me how it works! I'll be printing this out to test it soon!
I have uploaded some example STLs to show what it can do.

Objective: Students should learn to easily be able to model inorganic covalent compounds. Audience: Chemistry students from middle school through college. Preparation: Rudimentary knowledge of covalent bonding required. Preparation: Pick a compound that you want to model. (ex. glucose) Print the necessary atoms for it. (6 carbon, 12 hydrogen, 6 oxygen) Print the bonds of the required length. Assemble. Result: Result: You have modeled a chemical compound! Experiment by trying to create different compounds with different structures. (crystalline, molecular, etc.)

Please watch this video for more information: https://youtu.be/hH4L06uxcRU The survey for my next project has been closed. I'll have a video posted shortly detailing the winner and my plans to create it! This is the non electronic version of the R2-D2 robot I created here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1205821 I removed all of the parts specific to holding electronic components, and instead of using screws to hold the whole thing together, I made little cylindrical connectors. You can see those in the "extras" file. The tallest ones are used to connect the body to the arms/legs. The mid sized ones are used to connect the butt plate to the middle leg. The smaller ones are used to connect the body to the butt plate. These connectors should be pretty tight so they'll probably hold pretty well but some simple glue will make them stick together if it's not staying. The head will just slide on, and once you turn it, it should fall into a groove so the head can rotate but it shouldn't fall off easily. Also I have not actually printed this myself, so let me know if there are any issues while you're trying to print and I'll attempt to fix them. But everything should be printable at 0.3mm layer height and all the supports needed are already on the models. Also this model should be scalable to some degree. The pegs make it hard to do so, but you should be fine downsizing it a bit. I hope you enjoy this model! Post if you make one!

description.text:
I added some wide sections to the bottom of the track link to make it look more like a real tread.  I removed the weight reducing holes in one of the drive gears and added holes that allow a standard servo horn to be screwed to the wheel.
When printing the tread links, use support to hold up the hinge sections when it is printed.  This seems to work quite well so far.  I print about 40 at a time.  They will need some cleanup with a file and drill bit when complete.
Kudos to the original design by mscourch.  I really liked how simple his design was.

I have got a lot of questions about the firmware for the Sunhokey prusa i3. The prusa is arduino based. So i put the marlin RC1 firmware here. I have added the configuration.h file that I have changed to match the Sunhokey prusa i3 (MKS Gen-2Z v1.1) You have to change the Extruder Esteps/mm. This depends on type of filament and spring pressure.... " #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80.0, 80.0,400*1.014,100.7} "
In this case the last value "100,7" The "how to" is available on the internet. I put one example here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2zecUFRooN8 the latest version of Marlin can be downloaded from: https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin The configuration.h file can be diferent! !!!!! This is the basic version. No Auto Bed Levelling !!!!! At last I put a test file in for calibration. It's dimensions are 40 x 40 x 4 mm. There is a hole of 10mm and a hole of 20mm.
